1.0  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

    

US Vanadium, LLC (US Vanadium), uses anhydrous ammonia (AA) as a reactant in the recovery of vanadium products, chlorine (Cl2), and titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4) in the halide manufacturing process. The AA, Cl2, and TiCl4 are regulated substances under the Accidental Release Program regulations, which governs the Risk Management Plan Rule (RMP Rule).  Certain safety precautions must be observed when handling these chemicals to prevent unnecessary human exposure and to reduce the threat to employees and nearby members of the community.  It is US Vanadium policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which these chemicals are handled, training of personnel who operate the processes, and the safety devices inherent in the design of the storage vessels. 



The emergency response program presents a logical, coordinated course of action to be followed in case of an emergency.  The program utilizes information from the Emergency Response Guidebook by the Department of Transportation.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and notification of any potentially affected neighbors.



2.0  US VANADIUM AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



US Vanadium includes a vanadium recovery process and a halides manufacturing process. Anhydrous ammonia is used to aid in the recovery of the vanadium product in a crystallization circuit. Chlorine is introduced into the vanadium halide production process as a reactant. Titanium tetrachloride is blended with vanadium oxytrichloride to form vanadium-titanium mixtures.  The AA, Cl2, and TiCI4 are the only chemicals that the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has identified on the RMP Rule Toxic Substances list which are stored on site above threshold quantities. US Vanadium has no flammable substances regulated by the RMP Rule.  Storage conditions for the toxic chemicals r

3.0  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

    

As part of the general prevention program, US Vanadium has integrated chemical-specific prevention steps that help minimize the possibility of any leak of a hazardous substance that poses a potential danger both onsite and offsite.  US Vanadium's Process Safety Management (PSM) program for AA, Cl2, and TiCl4 follows the requirements of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) standards (29 CFR 1910.119). Although the PSM program has been developed to follow the guidelines of the OSHA PSM standard, it should be noted that the US Vanadium facility is under the jurisdiction of the Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA).  The requirements for the prevention program take a proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of regulated substances that pose a danger to human health and the environment. This prevention program is a vital part of everyday operations at US Vanadium, as safety is the chief priority. The program employs high standards and includes the following steps and programs that lead to successful accident prevention. 



3.1  Process Safety Information



Process safety includes information pertaining to the hazards of the substances in the covered processes as well as technology and equipment required for the processes. This information, updated regularly, helps to educate all employees on the current status of covered processes. The chemical hazards of

the process chemicals used at the US Vanadium facility are covered by the Safety Data Sheets (SDS) and the Hazard Communication (HAZCOM) program required by MSHA in 30 CFR Part 47.   



Information pertaining to the technology of the process and the equipment in the process is compiled in the PSM program. 



3.2  Process Hazard Analysis



US Vanadium's current PSM program includes Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations for its covered substances following Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP) methodologies. Recommendations resulting from the PHA are promptly addressed following the completion of the review. Resolutions to the recommendations are performed and documented as soon as possible and a schedule for resolution of recommendations resulting from the PHA is developed and kept on-file in the PSM program. 

 



3.3  Operating Procedures



The PSM program has documented procedures for each operating phase of US Vanadium's processes covered by the PSM program. Standard operating procedures (SOPs) for each department are kept on the server for electronic access. These SOPs are also readily accessible to employees. The SOPs are revised as needed as part of their ongoing review and reflect the most current operating practices of the covered processes. Included in the SOPs are practices for such operations as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, hot work permits, and safe work permits. The SOPs address elements for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions. 



3.4  Training



Operating and maintenance personnel at US Vanadium, as well as any contract employees, as required by the PSM regulation, must be trained in an overview of the process and in the developed operating procedures. This training must emphasize specific safety and health hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices.  



Initial training must occur bef

ore an employee's assignment to a PSM covered process. The Loss Control Program and Employee Training Program outline the procedures for achieving this goal and it is the responsibility of the Area Supervisor/Superintendent to document that employees complete the required training.  



Refresher training will be completed at least every three years.  Refresher training may be completed more often if the plant management determines, through consultation with operation personnel, that it is needed. Training will be documented and kept on file by management. Training documentation indicates whether the employee received and understood the training required by the regulation.



3.5  Mechanical Integrity



The General Manager is responsible for adherence to the Mechanical Integrity program by US Vanadium facility personnel and contractors.  The Mechanical Integrity program for the US Vanadium facility is maintained and implemented by the Maintenance and Engineering Department. US Vanadium personnel completing inspection, maintenance, and preventive maintenance includes plant technicians, maintenance, and engineering personnel. A level of knowledge of mechanical and electrical equipment, process hazards, and safe work practices is required within the job description and within other elements of the PSM program.



Inspection and testing will be documented as described in the Mechanical Integrity program maintained by the Maintenance and Engineering Department.  Equipment deficiencies found during routine operation, maintenance activities, or tests/inspections will be addressed before further use or in a safe and timely manner when necessary means are taken to assure safe operation.



The program coincides with our Quality Assurance program and an important element of quality assurance is the consistent use of the Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Review.  



3.6 Management of Change



The Management of Change (MoC) procedures must address any change other

than "replacement in kind" made in or to a PSM covered process. Employees involved in operating a process, maintenance personnel, and contract employees whose job tasks will be affected by a change in the process shall be informed of the change and trained on the change prior to startup of the process or affected part of the process. Process safety information, operating procedures, safe work practices, and other facility operations must be reviewed, evaluated, and updated if the change covered by MoC affects those areas. The MoC procedures described in the Plant/Process Change Procedure will be utilized as part of the system to manage changes to covered processes. The Plant/Process Change Management Form must be utilized by personnel to document the required MoC information. The information gathered within the form will be kept on file at the Safety Office to track changes completed at the facility.



3.7  Pre-startup Reviews



US Vanadium's Management of Change Equipment Release program also requires that a safety review be performed before any change or modification to a process. This Pre-startup Reivew confirms that construction and equipment is in accordance with design specifications; safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate; and training of each employee involved in operating a process is complete. 



3.8  Compliance Audit



Compliance with PSM standards will be evaluated at least every three years through a documented audit to verify that the procedures and practices developed under the PSM standard are adequate and being followed.  Deficiencies noted during the audit will be annotated and reported to management.  Progress toward resolving deficiencies will be tracked after a ranking and prioritization of items requiring response.  Documentation that deficiencies have been corrected will be maintained with the audit. The two most recent compliance audit reports will be retained by the Environmental Manager or

plant management.  



3.9  Incident Investigation



An incident investigation occurs on any incident on-site that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a release of a regulated substance covered by the PSM program. The Incident Investigation Team consists of the Safety Manager, Area Supervisor/Superintendent, Environmental Manager, and/or the President of US Vanadium/General Manager with additional personnel augmenting the team as necessary according to the location and circumstances of the incident or near miss.  This team will be required to conduct interviews of witnesses, gather needed documentation, and complete a final report.  The investigation must be initiated within 48 hours of incidents or near misses.



The information gathered, recommendations made, and corrective actions required during the investigation will be documented within the Accident/Incident Investigation Report and kept on file in the Safety Office.   Information within the Accident/Incident Investigation Report will be retained for at least five years. Personnel whose job tasks are relevant to the investigation findings, including applicable contract employees, shall review the Accident/Incident Investigation Report.



3.10  Employee Participation



It is the policy of US Vanadium to encourage employee participation in all facets of plant operation. The program allows for constant input from operators in such areas as Process Safety Information, Process Hazards Analyses, training, and Management of Change. 



3.11  Hot Work Permits



US Vanadium maintains specific procedures for obtaining a permit to perform maintenance, including hot work, in any area that could possibly affect a process involving a PSM covered processes. 



3.12  Contractors



US Vanadium maintains strict standards for contractors and their employees who perform any process-related work on-site. Applicable contractors must be evaluated and approved prior to being allowed to work at the facility.  Co

nfirmation of the approved contractor's receipt and understanding of the Contractor Safety Requirements will be documented and maintained on file at the facility. Approved contractors are responsible for their contract employees being properly trained or instructed to perform work in compliance with the US Vanadium safety, health, and environmental standards.



4.0  CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



4.1  Anhydrous Ammonia



Several process controls are in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental releases of AA.  These controls include vents, relief valves, check valves, manual and automatic shut-offs, interlocks, alarms, and excess flow devices.  



4.2  Chlorine



Several process controls are in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental release of Cl2.  These controls include a chlorine monitoring system, vents, relief valves, check valves, rupture disks, manual and automatic shut-offs, interlocks, scrubbers, emergency air supply, grounding equipment, excess flow devices, and fuse plugs.  



4.3  Titanium Tetrachloride



Several process controls are in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental release of TiCl4.  These controls include fusible plugs, manual shut-offs, scrubbers, purge system, designated storage areas, and limited quantities.  



5.0  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



5.1  Anhydrous Ammonia



During the past five years, US Vanadium has not had an accidental AA release resulting in on-site or off-site site consequences, including death, injury, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.



5.2 Chlorine



During the past five years, US Vanadium has not had an accidental Cl2 release resulting in on-site or off-site site consequences, including death, injury, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.



5.3  Titanium Tetrachloride



During the past five years, US Vanadium has not had an accidental TiCl4 release resulting in on-site

or off-site consequences, including death, injury, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.



6.0  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS



Emergency planning and response procedures are documented in US Vanadium's Emergency Procedures Handbook. A copy of the document is available electronically on the company server. This plan will be updated as necessary when modifications are made to the facility.



US Vanadium's Emergency Procedures Handbook provides information regarding the actions to be taken by employees in the event of an emergency and describes evacuation procedures and procedures for handling releases including small releases (e.g. use of B-Kit for chlorine leak). US Vanadium's Safety and Health Department is responsible for briefing employees once every year on the contents of the Emergency Procedures Handbook. A Security Committee is assigned to provide guidance and to carry out the procedures outlined in the Emergency Procedures Handbook.



The emergency response plan developed has been coordinated with the Garland County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and local emergency responders.  In addition, US Vanadium is included in the Garland County Hazardous Material Emergency Operations Plan.



7.0  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



US Vanadium conducts Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) at least every 5 years to identify and analyze the significance of potential hazards associated with the processing or handling of highly hazardous chemicals. The PHAs provide information to assist US Vanadium in improving safety and reducing the consequences of releases of hazardous chemicals.  Information provided by the PHAs is used to analyze potential causes and consequences of fires, explosions, releases of toxic or flammable chemicals, and major spills of hazardous chemicals. 



Process Hazard Analyses, utilizing the HAZOP analysis methodology, are routinely completed for the following processes at the US Va

nadium facility:

? Vanadium Halides and Solutions Project PHA

? Modified Vanadium Oxide PHA

? Solvent Extraction Circuit PHA



Upon completion of the PHAs (initial and updates), a report of findings, or "punch list", is developed and action items are ranked in order of greatest risk.  Items with the greatest risk will be addressed first. However, if easy, quick, inexpensive, or procedural fixes can be accomplished without taking resources away from the high risk items, those easy fixes are completed and, with proper documentation, removed from the list.  Documentation of this punch list, progress toward completion of those items, and PHA documentation are maintained in the Safety Office. Currently, US Vanadium utilizes an electronic work order system to schedule and track completion of each item.  The Maintenance Supervisor is responsible for making sure each item is completed and checked off.
